Iraq's marshlands at one time sustained as many as half a million people, but when the people known as the marsh Arabs supported a Shiite uprising after the 1991 Gulf War, Saddam Hussein built dams, dikes and canals to deflect water away from the 3,600-square-mile basin between the Tigris and Euphrates rivers.
Water to marshlands was allowed to flow once again after the US invasion of Iraq, and the area is starting to look again like what some people thought was the biblical Garden of Eden.
The United Nations environmental program this week reported that the marshes have recovered to about 40 percent of their original size.
And joining us now is Azzam Alwash of the Eden project.
We spoke with him two years ago, and he's back with us today for an update.
He joins us on the line from Tokyo.
Nice to speak with you again.
Nice to talk to you again, Neal.
What does it mean that the marshes have recovered, or have the marshes recovered, or at least there's water there?
Oh, my goodness, Neal.
There's actually--before I came to talk to you, I was in Montreal attending a scientific conference publishing the results of our two years' worth of collection of data.

And the scientific conclusion of monitoring the areas that have been inundated and recovered indicates that the biodiversity, for some strange reason, of the re-inundated areas is, in fact, more diverse and more vigorous than the portion of the marshes that remained undried, the 7 percent that existed between Iraq and Iran, the Hawizeh Marsh.

And this is actually probably a support for the theory of evolution, as it were, in the sense that the drying caused possibly the survival of the most vigorous of these seed beds, and the more dynamic of the species that were basically on the perimeter of the marshes.
And the reintroduction of the water caused a cycle of rebirth that is even stronger than the static conditions of the Hawizeh Marsh.
We're still trying to look at the data and trying to figuring out why is that.
It's an incredible story.
